content.webTitle: Kyle Langford sees World’s 800m final as a stepping stone to London 2017

fields.headline: Kyle Langford sees Beijing final as a stepping stone to London 2017
fields.bodyText: When David Rudisha lined up for the 800m final at the London 2012 Olympics, Kyle Langford had never heard of him. Just three years later, the 19-year-old from north London hopes to face the great Kenyan in the 800m final at the world championships final in Beijing. And within two years, Langford intends to be the best two-lap runner on the planet. Clearly he is not short of confidence. Then again, he is not short of ability either. He won the European Under‑23 title this summer and at the Anniversary Games last month he ran a personal best of 1min 45.78sec – a time that puts him 0.01 behind Steve Ovett on the British all-time junior list. And what makes Langford’s achievements more impressive is that he only took up track and field four years ago after regularly getting injured playing football, cricket and rugby. “One day in 2011 my school needed people to do athletics and I just decided to do the 200m,” he explains. “I did it and then got asked to join a club and it kind of started from there.” A year later he watched the sport properly for the first time at the London Olympics. “I knew who Usain Bolt was, but that was really about it,” he says. “But I’ve raced against Rudisha three times now and [the Olympic silver medallist] Nijel Amos twice. I’ve got a bit of experience of racing against these guys so we’ll just see how much more I can pick up at the world championships.” When asked about how good he can be, Langford does not do qualifiers. “I’m pretty confident I can run a lot faster,” he says. “If you look at the race [at the Anniversary Games] I was less than a second and a half behind guys who have run 1:42 this season. It shows I’m in pretty good stead for where my season can end up. It’d be good if I can get a PB and I will give my best to make it through the heat and the semi-finals. For me it’s just a learning curve so one day I can better the guys like Ovett and Seb Coe.” Those are strong words, especially for a runner who is ranked only 60th in the world. But Langford has improved his personal best by nearly two seconds in 2015 and feels there is plenty more to come. “I don’t want to be in it to just be a good GB runner or a good world runner,” he says. “I want to be the best.” In the past Langford has suggested that he might be good enough to aim for gold at next year’s Rio Olympics, but now he thinks the London 2017 world championships are more realistic. “That will definitely be the year I’ll go for the gold,” he says. “Next Olympics it will just be about making the final and who knows what will happen, I might surprise myself, but I’m pretty sure I’ll be happy to make the final. I still think I can get a medal, but it’s about actually doing it on the day.” And in Beijing, if he gets to line up alongside the world’s biggest names, he insists he will not freeze. “In the call room I sometimes sit there getting my spikes on and just smile,” he says. “It’s nice being around these guys. And I feel like I was meant to be there.”
